segments.text: All right, we just reviewed Intel's
highestend Panther Lake CPU, the Core
Ultra X9. And guys, it is fantastic. The
best thing that has come out of a CPU
manufacturer in years. One of the great
things, of course, about it is the new
B390 integrated GPU. We found it
performs similar to a low-end dedicated
GPU like say an RTX 4050 or 50/50, at
least at lower wattage. But in that
video, we only tested three games and a
bunch of synthetic benchmarks. Those are
games that do do a good job of showing
how a GPU performs verse others, but
they're certainly not the games that
many of you are playing, including me,
guys. So, today we are back and we're
going to show you how the X9 performs in
10 of the most popular titles at various
different settings. We're going to start
with graphically intensive ones and
we're going to walk our way down to
esports titles. Now, we're once again
going to be using the Zenbook Duo
because it has the highest end Panther
Lake chip and it can actually run it at
full power, 45 watt sustained. If you
did see our initial review, you may have
noticed that in Forza, the Duo performed
a little better on its standard mode. We
actually retested this and we found its
highest performance mode was indeed
better and that is the mode that we're
going to use today throughout the
testing. All of our other tests from
that original video were on performance
mode, so nothing else for me to bring up
on that one. All right, Arc Raiders, a
fairly demanding title. The game can run
well on low to medium settings. That's
on the display's native resolution of
2880 by 18800. We used XSS upscaling to
achieve these results. Intel has several
options available. Ultra performance
renders at the lowest base resolution,
so it gives you the most frames, but the
least visual quality. Ultra quality, on
the other hand, does the opposite. It
renders at a higher base resolution, so
the game looks better, but you don't get
as many extra frames. Now, you may be
wondering why we just didn't run the
game at a lower resolution. Surely, it
will be fine on a small 14-in display,
particularly say 1440 by 900, which is a
quarter of this display's native
resolution.
Two issues with this approach. Firstly,
you'd lose the anti-aliasing that
upscaling provides. So, diagonal lines
and edges, they just wouldn't appear as
sharp. Secondly, the UI elements would
be a bit fuzzy, like your ammo counter
or mini map. With upscaling, the UI is
actually rendered at the display's
native resolution. It's only the
gameplay itself that is upscaled. Back
on Arc Raiders, we found XSS ultra
performance at medium settings was the
best balance of visual fidelity and
playability and average FPS close to 70
and 1% lows of 44. If you do want more
frames, you can drop down to low
settings. On that setting, you can even
up XSS a notch to performance. We felt
the bump up in visual quality of medium
settings was worth the performance hit.
Now, on all settings we tried, we did
notice some occasional hitching in this
game. You'd be running around and there
was a sudden stutter. Unreal Engine 5
games are notorious for such issues, and
that is well documented. We also noticed
this in Fortnite, which is another UE5
game. We actually tested that game on a
much more powerful gaming laptop, the
Asus Zephris G16 with the 5070 Ti. It
also exhibited the occasional micro
stutter, so likely not an Intel issue.
Next up, we have the 2025 award-winning
game CLA obscure expedition 33. This
title is really hitting the limit of
what this X9 processor can handle. Even
on the lowest possible settings, you're
still getting sub 60 frames per second
on average. That being said, this game
is still somewhat playable. We had a
little debate about this one in the
office. You see, all of us agree that
for a title like this one that isn't a
fast-paced game, you can get away with
less frames. That being said, I wouldn't
want to play on anything that didn't hit
around 50 to 60 FPS on average. Now,
Seth and Sierra felt lower is okay.
That's if you're used to console or
handheld gaming where you can get less
than 60 FPS. Now, if you are going to
play CLA on this hardware, we recommend
setting XSS to performance. You see,
even though you lose a couple of frames
on ultra performance, the game just
lacked clarity. On that note, we did
find the visual fidelity looked a good
amount better if you step up to the
game's medium settings, especially
lighting. I'm going to call a spade a
spade, though. The integrated GPU in the
X9, it really isn't going to give you
the experience you probably want in this
game. Next, we tried Space Marine 2. We
knew this one was going to be rough
going in, so we only tried the lower
settings with FSR upscaling set to ultra
performance. Unfortunately, Space Marine
2, it doesn't support Intel's native
XSS. Frame rates were a little below 60
fps and 1% lows were below 40. That
being said, it didn't look horrendous
and it was playable. It's only once you
compare its image quality to a higherend
gaming laptop that you can really see
what you're missing out on. On the
Zephris G16 with a 5070Ti on high
settings, you can just see how much
detail is lost on the Duo. The Duo's
image looks really soft by comparison.
Next, we tried Monster Hunter Wilds.
This game is just too much for this
hardware no matter what settings you run
on. On the lower settings, sure, it was
a little more playable, but on those
settings, it just looked ugly and
blurry, and it was still a bit choppy.
All right, we then tried Call of Duty
War Zone. We tried the basic preset,
which is one up from the lowest, as well
as the next best, which is balanced.
Average FPS was pretty decent on both.
However, this is a fast-paced
competitive shooter. If you're just
trying to have a bit of fun, sure, you
can enjoy gaming on this processor. If
you're playing competitively, though, we
wouldn't recommend it. The 1% lows
and.1% lows are just too rough. Next, we
tried the Cyberpunk benchmark. It's an
older title, so its average FPS and 1%
lows were pretty decent at lower
settings with upscaling on. Just a
little note on its benchmark. We did
notice this weird visual artifact across
the bottom of the screen when we turned
on XSS. This did not occur though in
actual gameplay. All right, on to
esports titles. Starting with a Marvel
Rivals benchmark. This is a surprisingly
heavy game and we did have to drop right
down to its lower settings to get above
60 fps on average. When using XSS Ultra
performance, Objects in Motion though,
they had a lot of temporal artifacts.
They just didn't look clear. Obviously,
not ideal for competitive play. The
issue is if you just change XSS to
performance and keep the other game
settings, you're below 60fps.
Once again, if you just want to have a
bit of fun on an Ultrabook, yes, it is
playable. But if you are serious about
this game, this hardware just isn't good
enough. Now, in the latest version of
XSS, Intel supports multiframe
generation up to three AI generated
frames for every real one. Marvel Rivals
and Cyberpunk, they do support this, so
we tried it in our original video.
Unsurprisingly, we got more average
frames, but we didn't get better 1%
lows, which is what you probably want
more. This is a common issue on frame
generation and it does happen on gaming
laptops too with higherend GPUs from
Nvidia. That's where the 1% lows don't
improve with frame generation. Also, and
more importantly, if your base frame
rate is below 60, as it is with a lot of
games on this hardware, the input lag
becomes very noticeable. Next up, we
have Fortnite. It was very playable. We
weren't even running on its slowest
possible settings. We used medium with
XSS on balanced. The average frame rates
and 1% lows were pretty good. You can
even go up to high settings if you turn
off nanite and lumen. You may notice in
our results that.1% lows were really
rough. We actually tested Fortnite on
the same Zephris with a 5070Ti that we
used for Space Marine testing that I
showed you earlier. It also got very
bad.1% lows in Fortnite at the same game
settings as the Duo. Just look at the
drop down from the average to.1%
170 frames per second down to 34. Once
again, we feel this is an Unreal Engine
5 thing and our testers said it didn't
affect playability. Before we leave
Fortnite, we've tested a lot of games
with upscaling on, as you've seen
throughout this video. If you're
wondering if you need to do that, here's
Fortnite rendered at the display's
native resolution without upscaling.
XSS, as you can see, it does make a big
difference. On this kind of hardware,
it's kind of clutch unless you're
playing something like Counterstrike.
On that note, on Counterstrike 2, we
tested on medium settings and we didn't
use upscaling. The results were really
good. Even.1% lows were above 60 FPS.
So, Counter-Strike 2, unsurprisingly,
very playable and enjoyable on this
hardware. Finally, I played my game
League of Legends. Obviously, I expected
it to run very well. If you're unaware,
I play a lot of competitive League, just
way too much. So, I kind of tested it
from that angle. I ran on medium
settings on the screen's native
resolution, and I got pretty good
results above 60 fps, even for 1% lows.
But I have a cherry on top for you. The
results that you are seeing on screen
right now are actually while I was
simultaneously streaming to Twitch. This
Asus Duo, it's a dual screen laptop, so
it is ideal for something like that. And
guys, seriously, isn't it amazing that
this laptop can even do this? Now, I did
actually try several other league
settings earlier in the day, but I
realized I was gaming on battery, and I
didn't even know I was gaming on
battery. If you've ever experienced
gaming on battery on an Nvidia laptop,
you definitely notice the moment you are
unplugged. Performance, it just drops
through the floor. Well, with this
laptop, performance is identical on
battery. As I said, I didn't even know I
was unplugged. And Sierra, she said the
same thing, who also accidentally played
a couple of rounds of Fortnite
unplugged. So, the only thing remaining
is how long can you game on battery?
Well, Seth ran the Forza benchmark on
repeat until the laptop died with a
screen at 300 nits of brightness on its
highest performance mode. As mentioned,
it pulled the full 45 W the entire time.
Unfortunately though, it only lasted an
hour and a half. This makes sense as it
has a 99Wh battery. 45 W plus another 20
or so for the rest of the laptop and
bang, you get around 1.5 hours. But hold
your horses. Depending on your game, you
may be able to run on standard
performance mode for better battery
life. In a GPUheavy game like Forza, you
only lose around 8% of gaming
performance for a big saving in power
draw. That's on that mode. You see, on
standard performance mode, the laptop
draws 35 W. Now, this may be a bit
crippling though for CPU dependent games
as we found that's where most of the
power saving comes from. Anyway, this
leads me to my final point. As a team,
we all feel that this processor is going
to be phenomenal in a handheld. You see,
handhelds have significantly lower
resolution screens to drive. We're
actually thinking of doing a video where
we test a Panther Lake laptop with
settings that essentially make it a
gaming handheld just to show you what
you can expect. Now, if that sounds
interesting to you, just drop a comment
down below. With that said, let's wrap.
Overall, Intel have done a phenomenal
job here. This GPU is way better than
any other integrated GPU for a gaming
thin and light. Yes, AMD has Stricks
Halo, but that's still just really hard
to find. It's just not in a lot of
laptops. In fact, if you're picking
between a laptop with an X9 processor
and a lower wattage Nvidia GPU, I'd
definitely get the X9. As we
demonstrated in our original video, that
chip is just much more power efficient
than Nvidia's ones. That's why you can
game at full performance when unplugged.
This being said, let's call it as it is.
The X9 chip, it still delivers basic
gaming performance. It's very good in
less demanding titles, but in demanding
ones, games are barely playable, as we
showed you. So, it certainly doesn't
unseat a mid-range gaming laptop with
something like an RTX 5060. In fact,
that leads me to how I want to end this
video. I want to end it with a challenge
to Intel. do what AMD did with Stricks
Halo and come out with a beefier version
of this GPU with 40 cores rather than
12. That would just really put the hurt
on Nvidia and right now given how
anti-gamer Nvidia seems to have become
people would just switch to you to Intel
in droves. Anyway, with that said, if
you're in the market to buy a laptop
right now, make sure to check out our
website, bestlaptop.deals.
Over there, we are demystifying laptop
shopping. We even have this new filter
so you can quickly find all these new
Panther Lake laptops. Get subscribed
with the notification bell on. We have a
lot more reviews coming and videos
coming on these new laptops. Till next
time, go do something awesome with your
day and I will catch you later. Josh
out.
